To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee.term: To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee
To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee.passage: To Kill a Mockingbird is a novel by Harper Lee published in 1960. It was immediately successful, winning the Pulitzer Prize, and has become a classic of modern American literature. The plot and characters are loosely based on Lee's observations of her family and neighbors, as well as on an actual case in her hometown of Monroeville, Alabama. The novel is set in the 1930s in the fictional "tired old town" of Maycomb, Alabama, the seat of Maycomb County. The story is narrated by Jean Louise Finch, also known as Scout, a young girl whose father, Atticus Finch, is a lawyer. Atticus defends Tom Robinson, a black man accused of raping a white woman, Mayella Ewell. The trial and its aftermath are a central part of the novel. The title of the novel refers to the idea that it is a sin to kill a mockingbird, a harmless bird that only sings for the pleasure of it. The mockingbird is a symbol of innocence and goodness, and the novel explores the themes of racial injustice and the destruction of innocence. The novel also deals with the issues of class and social status in the Deep South. The Ewell family, who are poor and uneducated, are portrayed as uncouth and uncivilized, while the Finch family, who are middle-class and educated, are portrayed as refined and civilized. To Kill a Mockingbird has been widely praised for its portrayal of racism and its exploration of moral issues. It has been translated into more than 40 languages and has sold over 40 million copies worldwide.

The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald.passage: The Great Gatsby is a 1925 novel by American writer F. Scott Fitzgerald. It follows a cast of characters living in the fictional towns of West Egg and East Egg on prosperous Long Island in the summer of 1922. The story primarily concerns the young and mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby and his quixotic passion and obsession for the beautiful former debutante Daisy Buchanan. The novel explores themes of decadence, idealism, social upheaval, and excess, creating a portrait of the Jazz Age that has been described as a cautionary tale regarding the American Dream. The Great Gatsby has been widely regarded as a literary classic and a contender for the title "Great American Novel". The novel is written in a style that is both modernist and experimental, with a narrator who is unreliable and whose interpretation of events is constantly questioned. The narrator, Nick Carraway, is a young man who has moved to New York from the Midwest to pursue a career in finance. He becomes friends with Gatsby and is drawn into his world of excess and decadence. The novel is also notable for its use of symbolism, such as the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, which represents Gatsby's hopes and dreams, and the eyes of Dr. T.J. Eckleburg, which symbolize the loss of spiritual values in American society. The story follows the main character, Elizabeth Bennet, as she deals with issues of manners, upbringing, morality, education, and marriage in the society of the landed gentry of early 19th-century England. Elizabeth is the second of five sisters in a family living in the fictional town of Longbourn in Hertfordshire, near London. The story opens with the arrival of a wealthy young bachelor, Mr. Charles Bingley, who rents the nearby Netherfield Park. He brings with him his sister and his friend, Mr. Darcy. Elizabeth Bennet is initially not impressed with Mr. Darcy, as she finds him to be proud and aloof. However, as she gets to know him better, she begins to see that her initial impressions were unfounded. Mr. Darcy, in turn, becomes increasingly attracted to Elizabeth, but his pride and his belief that he is not good enough for her lead him to make some poor decisions. The novel also explores the relationships between the various members of the Bennet family, including Elizabeth's elder sister, Jane, and her eventual husband, Mr. Bingley. The novel also features the character of Mr. Collins, a pompous and obsequious clergyman who is a cousin of Mr. Bennet and who is seeking a wife. Pride and Prejudice has been adapted for film and television numerous times, and it remains a popular and influential novel today. It is often considered a classic of English literature and a defining work of the Regency era.

Tolkien was born in Bloemfontein, South Africa, to English parents, and moved to England with his family when he was three years old. He served as a second lieutenant in the Lancashire Fusiliers during World War I and was severely wounded at the Battle of the Somme. After the war, he returned to Oxford University, where he studied English language and literature, and eventually became a professor of Anglo-Saxon at Pembroke College. Tolkien's academic work focused on the study of Old and Middle English literature, and he was one of the foremost experts in the field of Anglo-Saxon studies. His academic work influenced his fiction writing, and he created a detailed and complex mythology for his stories, drawing on his knowledge of Old English and other languages. Bilbo Baggins.passage: Bilbo Baggins is a fictional character in J.R.R. Tolkien's legendarium. He is a hobbit who lives in the Shire, a small, peaceful, and comfortable region of Middle-earth. He is the protagonist of Tolkien's 1937 novel The Hobbit, and also appears in The Lord of the Rings. Bilbo is described as a small, rotund, and rather elderly hobbit, with a long nose and a fondness for pipe-smoking. He is initially content to live a quiet life in his hobbit-hole, but his adventures begin when he is recruited by a group of dwarves to act as their burglar in their quest to reclaim their homeland from the dragon Smaug. Throughout the story, Bilbo demonstrates remarkable courage, resourcefulness, and cunning, and he becomes a key member of the group. He also develops a close friendship with the dwarf Thorin Oakenshield, and becomes a respected figure among the other creatures of Middle-earth. Bilbo's experiences on his journey with the dwarves have a profound effect on him, and he returns to the Shire a changed hobbit. He becomes more outgoing and adventurous, and he is no longer content to live a quiet life. He also becomes known as "Bilbo Baggins, the Magnificent", and his reputation as a great adventurer spreads throughout Middle-earth. Despite his success, Bilbo remains humble and modest, and he is always quick to credit his companions for their contributions to their shared adventures.
